czok.title: Czochralski Method
czok.trunc: Involves pulling a crystal (boule) upward from a molten solution. Produces some of the purest crystals but requires a cleanroom environment.
czok.desc:
The Czochralski Method is common process used in the production of artificial crystals and purified elements. Part of the reason for this process's popularity industrially comes from the fact that it produces exceptionally pure crystals when done properly. Compared to other methods, it's an optimal mix of speed and quality. However, it typically tends to be quite costly because of the strict parameters needed for production. It requires a chemically inert, high-temperature, durable crucible. These crucibles are often made of quartz, platinum, boron nitride, or other specialty materials depending on the type of crystal being grown. The device itself requires a cleanroom-grade setting to operate properly and eliminate impurity inclusion. The general process is simple. Solid ingredients in the crucible are melted into a liquid. The seed crystal is lowered into the molten material, and using precise magnetic rotation, the crystal is spun and pulled out of the mixture at a controlled speed. The result of this process is a 3-part columnar crystal called a boule.
The boule is made of a head, body, and tail. The head and tail are usually smaller and cone shaped. They can be thought of as the “terminations” of the crystal. Often, they're too small or can have impurities concentrated at a level that makes them useless, so they tend to be destroyed and remelted / repurified for future pulls. The body of the crystal is the main material of interest. An optimal boule will have a cylindrical body with a consistent width across the vertical axis. The shape of the boule is a limiter to what kind of materials can be produced from them. For example, Silicon boules grown with this method are often calibrated and grinded into perfect circular wafers. They choose this form factor because it makes optimal use of the boule's shape.
czok.history:
The process itself was discovered and developed by Polish scientist Jan Czochralski in 1915 entirely by accident. The story goes that Jan stuck a pen in molten tin, and while removing it, accidentally pulled a single filament of pure tin. This filament was found to be a singular monocrystal.
Jan refined and developed this process, until publishing a paper on his findings in 1918. Since then, the capabilities of this process have expanded to include production of just about anything crystalline, from elements, to semiconductors, to exotic materials, and as of more recently, synthetic crystals for use in the gem industry. To this day it remains one of the most widely relied upon methods of artificial crystallization.

vern.title: Verneuil Method
vern.trunc: Involves sputtering molten material onto a boule similarly to plasma coating. Produces gem-grade quickly and cheaply, but often with defects.
vern.desc:
The Verneuil Method, otherwise known by the trade name “Flame Fusion”, is a widely used and classic method of quick quality crystal production. It has a limited range of materials in which can be produced with it, but it allows very fast and very cheap growth. Finished boules can be grown in a matter of hours. The tradeoff is that they can be prone to impurities or defects in some situations. As such, it doesn’t tend to grow optics-quality material; However, it still produces gem-grade crystals. Certain materials (Such as Rutile) can be grown to optics-purity via careful parameter control and post-processing, such as annealing.
The general process for growth is very simple. It’s not unlike a plasma sputtering device. Solid ingredients are liquified and sputtered at high speeds and temperatures towards a base or a seed crystal. After several hours, this buildup of microscopic molten droplets quickly crystallizes into a solid boule.

hdth.title: Hydrothermal Method
hdth.trunc: Involves suspending a seed crystal into a high pressure / high temperature autoclave with liquid ingredients. Sometimes produces optics-grade ingots.

flux.title: Flux Method
flux.trunc: Involves suspending a seed crystal near or inside flux with ingredients. Allows lower-temperature production. Sometimes produces gem-grade crystals.

kyrp.title: Kyropoulos Method
kyrp.trunc: Derivative of the Czochralski method. Crystal grows into the feed material instead of being pulled. Can change the output purity and may be preferred.

zone.title: Zone Melting
zone.disc: John Desmond Bernal and William G. Pfann (Bell Laboratories)
zone.trunc: Involves passing cold / hot zones over a melt / seed to concentrate impurities in specific regions, while forming a monocrystalline ingot at the end of the path.

skul.title: Skull Melting
skul.trunc: Involves compressing ingredients into a puck, and using Induction Heating to cook the inside of the puck into CZ, structured like a brain in a skull.

brst.title: Bridgman Technique
brst.disc: Percy Williams Bridgman and Donald C. Stockbarger
brst.trunc: Related to the Czochralski method. Material is melted in a crucible and the crucible itself is moved slowly into a colder zone, allowing for crystallization.

hdsm.title: Horizontal Direction Solidification Method
hdsm.trunc: Related to the Bridgman technique. Material is melted and a crucible is moved horizontally instead of vertically, as with other methods.

hpht.title: High-Pressure High-Temperature Synthesis
hpht.trunc: Involves supplying extreme pressures / temperatures on ingredients or a seed crystal to produce larger crystals, which can then be used as seeds again or simply used on their own.

cvdp.title: Chemical Vapor Deposition
cvdp.trunc: Involves leeching specialty gasses onto a heated / pressurized environment with seed crystals. Slowly builds up atomic layers of material until a solid crystal is produced.

sint.title: Sintering and Annealing
sint.trunc: An umbrella of methods involving heat treatment or controlled heating / burning to form solids and crystals. Often used for making polycrystalline media or annealing monocrystalline media.

frcr.title: Fractional Crystallization
frcr.trunc: A simple method of crystallization involving stages of temperature changes to pull crystals out of a solution.

frfr.title: Fractional Freezing
frfr.trunc: A simple method of crystallization involving melted ingredients shifting down to certain temperatures to isolate or purify certain materials

eptx.title: Epitaxy
eptx.trunc: An umbrella of methods revolving around film or layer-based crystallization. Can involve phase changes, temperature changes, among other factors.

lhpg.title: Laser-Heated Pedestal Growth
lhpg.trunc: A process involving melting a transition zone within a crystal using lasers. Similar to Zone Melting.

mpdn.title: Micro-Pulling Down
mpdn.trunc: A method involving a heated crucible with an orifice on the bottom. A seed crystal is placed through the bottom and is slowly pulled down, forming a monocrystalline rod / fiber.

edfg.title: Edge-Defined Film-Fed Growth
edfg.trunc: A method that involves pulling a seed through a vertical channel, with a die that feeds a film of molten material upward.

rclz.title: Recrystallization
rclz.trunc: A simple method of purifying materials by dissolving a crystal in a solvent and letting the desired compound precipitate / crystallize out of solution

evap.title: Evaporative Crystallization
evap.trunc: A simple method of crystallization done by drying a solution until the solute concentration is high enough, and it crystallizes into a solid.

cool.title: Cooling Crystallization
cool.trunc: A simple method of crystallization that involves slowly cooling a liquid until it stabilizes and freezes into a crystalline solid.
